TRANSPORT OF CONTAINERS AND PETROLEUM: PROPOSALS
asked the Minister of Transport and Highways:
(i) whether he admits the fact that a large number of containers are transported to Colombo Port from different areas of Sri Lanka annually;
(ii) whether it has been proposed that the Sri Lanka Railways can transport the aforesaid containers to Colombo Port;
(iii) If so, of such proposals; and
(iv) whether the aforesaid proposals have been implemented as of now?
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) whether it has been proposed that the Sri Lanka Railways could transport the petroleum imported to different areas;
(ii) If so, of such proposals; and
(iii) whether the aforesaid proposals have been implemented as of now?

APPROVED ACADEMIC AND NON-ACADEMIC CADRES IN
(a) Will he inform this House, separately -
(i) the approved academic cadre and non-academic cadre in each of the State universities in Sri Lanka;
(ii) the breakdown of permanent staff in terms of different categories in each of the above universities;
(iii) the vacancies that exist in the approved cadre by now in each of the State universities; and
(iv) faculty-wise vacancies that exist in the University of Colombo, University of Jaffna, University of Ruhuna, University of Rajarata and University of Peradeniya?

(b) Will he also inform this House, separately regarding each of the State universities - (i) the number of employees who are on postgraduate and/ or sabbatical leave by now; (ii) the number of employees who have vacated the post; (iii) the number of employees who resigned during the period from 2021 to 2023; and (iv) the number of academic staff on contract, visiting or temporary basis by now?
(c) If not, why? () ( () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Susil Premajayantha, Attorney-at-Law) , .

asked the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs:
(i) the number of archaeological monuments identified by the Department of Archaeology at present;
(ii) the name, the province, the district and the Divisional Secretary's Division of the location of each such archaeological monument, separately;
(iii) the number of archaeological monuments that have been declared by Gazette Notifications, as at 01.06.2023; and
(iv) the name, the province, the district and the Divisional Secretary's Division of the location of each such archaeological monument, separately?
(i) the number of archaeological monuments on which excavations and conservation activities are carried out, out of the archaeological monuments mentioned in the (a) (iii) above;
(ii) the name, the province, the district and the Divisional Secretary's Division of the location of each such archaeological monument, separately;
(iii) the number of archaeological monuments which have been declared by Gazette Notifications, but where conservation activities have not yet been carried out; and
(iv) the name, the province, the district and the Divisional Secretary's Division of the location of each such archaeological monument, separately?

: ROAD ACCIDENTS ON COLOMBO-KANDY MAIN ROAD:
) ( - . . . ) (The Hon. Kins Nelson on behalf of the Hon. M.W.D. Sahan Pradeep Withana) - (2):
asked the Minister of Transport and Highways :

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether he admits that an extensive number of road accidents take place in Sri Lanka presently; and (ii) the number of road accidents taken place near Indigahamula Junction on Colombo-Kandy Main Road during the last five years and the number of persons who lost lives due to the above accidents, separately corresponding to each year?

(b) Is he aware that - (i) there is an entrance way to Colombo-Kandy Main Road from the direction of Weboda; (ii) the vehicles entering that main road from Weboda Road are heading towards Kandy or Colombo; (iii) that a large number of accidents have taken place on the pedestrian crossing found in that place; (iv) the location of both the above pedestrian crossing and the entrance way in the same point has caused the above situation; and (v) no action has been taken so far despite notifications being given in this regard for many years?
(c) Will he also inform this House of the measures that will be taken to prevent the occurrence of road accidents at the above-mentioned place and to minimize loss of lives and property?
PARADISE LAKE IN KURUWITA: DIGGING ACTIVITIES
) ( - ) (The Hon. Kins Nelson on belf of the Hon. Vasudeva Nanayakkara)) - (2):

(i) a group of persons have planned to dig the bottom of Paradise Lake in Ratnapura, Kuruwita, up to about 30 feet, using machinery on the pretext of removing silt and sand and to transfer the gem bearing gravel to a different area;
(ii) as a result, the thick silt layer of the lake has been damaged and is on the verge of drying up; and
(iii) about 112 wells near the lake are on the verge of drying up and the houses of "Lake Side" villagers are at risk of getting cracks and subsiding?
(b) Will he inform this House whether -
(i) permission has been obtained from the relevant government authorities to dig the lake in the above manner;
(ii) if so, what is the depth permitted to be dug; and
(iii) an investigation is conducted regarding the environmental damage caused by the work referred to in (a)(i) above?

[11.21 a.m.] ( ) (The Hon. Eran Wickramaratne) Hon. Presiding Member, I would like to take this opportunity basically to pay tribute to a giant in the business community of this country, Merrill J. Fernando, who is no more. I recall, nearly 40 years ago, Dr. Gamani Corea, the Secretary-General of UNCTAD talking about stabilization of primary commodity prices of poor countries because our customers were in richer markets. And because of his inspiration, as a student, I wrote a thesis on Alternative Approaches to Tea Price Stabilization. In that, I said, Brand promotion merely transfers the revenues from one transnational corporation to another and is not of benefit to producers like Sri Lanka. It would be difficult for producers to compete in marketing retail teas as they would face competition from well-established transnationals, but they should seek to gain some control of the marketing system by buying shares in the transnational corporations. Despite the attendant difficulties, another way of ensuring the producer country teas are available on consumer country markets would be for producers to establish their own marketing organizations within consumer countries.

I had not heard of Merrill J. Fernando or about Dilmah as a brand when I did my thesis. Today, Sri Lanka is on the global map of value-added teas and Dilmah has also become a global brand in over 100 countries. A research students dream had been fulfilled. Three months ago, I was the beneficiary of the autobiography The Story of Ceylon Teamaker: Merrill J. Fernando, Disruptor, Teamaker, Servant, which was sent to me. It was only published three months ago and now, Mr. Fernando is no more. In the Introduction of the book, his sons Dilhan and Malik have stated, Our fathers life story is one that must be told because of its relevance to the life in the 21st Century. It is the classic tale of a young man with ambition beyond what convention dictated and offers an inspirational guide to ordinary women and men who have big dreams. This is also the story of extraordinary human kindness with a man whose determination, resilience and passion for tea have produced a business grounded genuinely in a commitment to the purpose beyond profit. His life demonstrates the goodness of God, in the improbable achievement of an ordinary Sri Lankan in hostile circumstances, driven and delivered by faith."

As a Member of Parliament, I have been personally acquainted with that individual, the MJF Charitable Foundation and its centre in Moratuwa. Amongst his numerous social initiatives benefiting more than 60,000 people are those that are carried out mainly in the plantation areas of this country. I have been touched when I got to know that there are over 300 children with Down syndrome, autism, cerebral palsy and other developmental disorders who have been benefitting from the daily programmes designed to meet their wide-ranging individual needs. So, the story of Merrill J. Fernando is purpose beyond tea. Therefore, we thank God for his life and may he rest in peace!

. , . . . Microfinance is a debt trap to women. Due to lethargy and failure of the public sector regulatory measures, the Government had to intervene incurring Rs. 500 million in 2018 alone. Who is responsible for such a debacle? . . . , survey microfinance companies 507 . survey , 115 . 15 , 115 . , ? . , 30 .

Announcing the first among the number of measures to be taken, this is what the Hon. Minister said that day: An estimated 75,000 women who obtained loans from finance companies and microfinance companies, which are members of the Lanka Microfinance Practitioners Association, and have three months' arrears as of 30th June, 2018 are entitled to receive the debt relief up to a ceiling of Rs. 100,000. However, more than 200 women had died committing suicide as they had to face sexual violence at the hands of microfinance lenders.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam. You have seven minutes.

.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Presiding Member, whilst we are debating this Banking (Special Provisions) Bill, I would like to associate myself and our party with the comments made by the Hon. Vijitha Herath. The main point of his intervention, Sir, was that whilst the Amendments that are being proposed have, at the surface, the intention for the Central Bank to take over financial institutions on occasions when, for example, they default and are going into trouble, the way in which these acts are interpreted, of course, is where everything ultimately lies. We also have a precedent in this country - you have what is known as the ICCPR Law - where that law is being interpreted by the authorities opposite to its true intentions. Sir, you, as a lawyer, know that it is a huge criticism that Sri Lanka faces not only among the victims of the ICCPR Act in Sri Lanka, but also among the international community.

Sir, Sri Lankas credibility, of course, is at its lowest, not only because of Sri Lankas reputation with regard to complete lack of democracy, lack of accountability and the crimes that have taken place, but also with regard to the way in which the notion of the rule of law is being adhered to in this country and the intention of those who are governing. Just take for example what the Hon. S. Viyalanderan, who spoke before me, mentioned. He spoke about certain views that were expressed yesterday by Sarath Weerasekera. I do not want to call him "Honourable". The Hon. Viyalanderan did not mention his name, but everybody knows that he is whom he spoke about. Now, that Member is the Chairman of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security. Can you believe it? A man who is a suspected war criminal, who

does not have the faintest idea of what the rule of law is, who has the audacity to be in contempt of court and be shielded by the Privileges of Parliament to threaten a magistrate and to make comments about a substantive matter that is before court is the Chairman of the Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Security. So, that is the nature of Sri Lankas way of handling these various matters, in which the international community would look for notions of democracy, the rule of law and accountability, financial and otherwise. Now, this Banking (Special Provisions) Bill is primarily to have financial accountability. You are bringing about these Amendments because if you do not build up a credible system, then, the international community is not going to have that sort of confidence to invest.

Then, we also have, Sir, the Hon. Suren Raghavan, who, yesterday, spoke quite emotionally in Sinhala criticizing the Tamil Members of Parliament elected from the North and the East, primarily stating that those Tamil Parliamentarians, being Tamil nationalists, talk of federalism, that federalism is secessionism and that we are trying to, again, inflame the emotions of the southern youth by talking about secessionism. This was utter nonsense! Sarath Weerasekera
[ .] [ ] [Expunged on the order of the Chair.]

is, at least, a war criminal and we can sort of expect him to say rubbish. But, Suren Raghavan claims to be an intellectual and a person with a doctorate. To equate federalism with secessionism shows his utter intellectual bankruptcy and intellectual dishonesty. He is making these comments, Sir, whilst the President is inviting the Tamil Parliamentarians to have discussions with regard to reconciliation.

And his suggestion is that the Tamils should not be talking about any of this and rather just adhere to the concept of democracy. I challenge the Hon. Raghavan and all those Members opposite, who try to say that the people elected from the North and the East do not represent the Tamils of the North and the East, to have a Referendum! If you want to know the true intention of the Tamil people, I challenge you to have a Referendum! You have a Referendum and ask whether the Tamil people are willing to accept a Unitary State or a federal State and if you have a backbone, ask whether the Tamil people want a separate State. Without you all sitting here pre-judging what the Tamil people want, if you have a backbone, ask the Tamil people what they want. Thereafter, if you want, you can come and preach us.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Hon. Member, your time is up. .. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) I am winding up, Sir.

So, without doing that, Sir, if these Members think that they can talk on behalf of the people of the North and the East and that they can threaten them - well, Sri Lanka has been threatened in the past, has suffered as a result and with these, those sufferings are going to be heaped again - no one with dignity will accept any of that.
Thank you. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Nalin Bandara Jayamaha. You have seven minutes.
. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Ranjith Siyambalapitiya. You have 29 minutes.
